interestingcomments.content: @johnkunstadter I contacted Camera Obscura Repairs direct through the 'Book a Repair' form, to which Alex replied directly and provided me with a booking form complete with instructions and an address. I had to include the form with my camera - probably helps to keep track of things. I forgot to mention that I was provided with an Inspection Report after Alex assessed my equipment prior to agreeing the go-ahead for service, which made the process transparent and understandable. Cheers J

interestingcomments.content: I ordered a replacement baseplate (used ) for my M3. It arrived, I put it on without the take up spool in just to see it fit ..all good. Was loading film and realised I could not close the baseplate and then I saw a Plastic 'thing', a sort of guide , screwed onto the take up side of the base plate which was apparently the issue. I unscrewed this 'thing and removed it and all was well. However my curiosity is asking , what is this thing? any thoughts ? best Andy --img--

interestingcomments.content: Maybe so, but with the people in the DxO forums, this seems to work well enough. I think that's enough. Nothing will ever be "perfect". I'm not going to worry about "eliminating variations". Before I calibrated my display, things were much worse. As far as I'm concerned, it's better to do what I can do, rather than to do nothing. I see no point in wasting time thinking of things I have no control over, but I was able to do the things the other forum members suggested. I guess that's "good enough". 🙂

interestingcomments.content: My pet hate is when people describe things like a lens rendition as "Organic". As far as I am concerned, this adjective only applies to chemical compounds containing carbon or vegetables/fruit/grain grown with poo but without insecticide. Wilson
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: My pet hate is when people describe things like a lens rendition as "Organic". As far as I am concerned, this adjective only applies to chemical compounds containing carbon or vegetables/fruit/grain grown with poo but without insecticide. Wilson

interestingcomments.content: What an interesting thread. It shows what a little lateral thinking can produce so thank you @Datsch for starting this process. Product evolution often means adding things so it's refreshing to see so many ideas for subtracting things. It sort of reminds me of Apple Computer. You may love 'em or hate 'em but you can't dispute they have driven change, both in functionality and design. And this change was often typified by the removal of things that many people said you simply couldn't do without. Things like floppy disk drives. How will we load programs without a floppy disk? Seems rather funny now when you look back on it. Same with CD or DVD drives, and Apple went for USB C when there were virtually no USB C peripherals. How stupid was that? Photography has changed so much in recent years but our little black box recording device (the camera) still has the same basic buttons etc. Maybe Leica will listen to @Datsch. I hope so. Edited August 4 by T25UFO
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: What an interesting thread. It shows what a little lateral thinking can produce so thank you @Datsch for starting this process. Product evolution often means adding things so it's refreshing to see so many ideas for subtracting things. It sort of reminds me of Apple Computer. You may love 'em or hate 'em but you can't dispute they have driven change, both in functionality and design. And this change was often typified by the removal of things that many people said you simply couldn't do without. Things like floppy disk drives. How will we load programs without a floppy disk? Seems rather funny now when you look back on it. Same with CD or DVD drives, and Apple went for USB C when there were virtually no USB C peripherals. How stupid was that? Photography has changed so much in recent years but our little black box recording device (the camera) still has the same basic buttons etc. Maybe Leica will listen to @Datsch. I hope so. Edited August 4 by T25UFO

interestingcomments.content: Added later - the above photo is also a demonstration of why anyone working on something like a Leica camera MUST have the proper tools. Regular, ordinary screwdrivers are NOT suitable for machine screws. Most people don't seem to realize this, and butcher up screws on whatever they are working on. Yuck. The same thing happens with gunsmiths. They have the proper tools for the job. Customers don't, and bring in their guns with the screw heads all butchered up like what I see above. Sorry for the interruption - I couldn't help it. Things like this really annoy me.
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: Added later - the above photo is also a demonstration of why anyone working on something like a Leica camera MUST have the proper tools. interestingcomments.content: My CL died in mid August, I sent it to Leica NJ US, the diagnosis was a failed circuit board and a out of adjustment sensor. I tried to get an idea of what caused this, even speculation would be better than nothing. Stacey McHenry Manager of Customer Care from Leica responded "I apologize, the technician is not able to determine what caused the problem, just that the circuit failed." I was kind of hoping it was some thing I had done, or something I could avoid. Guess asking a Leica tech for speculation isn't a thing.

interestingcomments.content: ^ ^ The critical thing for me is whether you need the Adobe software to be compatible with what other people are using. As far as I'm concerned in trying to produce a photobook Indesign is, in that you can send an "Indesign package" to a printshop or a lithographer and they can go straight to their imposition software. Otherwise, one could use alternatives to PS and LR. _______________________Frog Leaping photobook

interestingcomments.content: Those fakes, even when declared as such, bothers me. I always report them, but it probably doesn't help. Not that I can't laugh at some of the things that comes up, but they were not made for laughing but to dishonestly adding value to an object of lesser value.

interestingcomments.content: I think that anecdotal evidence about how the cameras of Tom, Dick and Harry all survived XYZ is reassuring. Of course cameras are like people... some folks have fallen from airplanes without a parachute and survived to tell the tale, while others have been killed by errant golf balls... and just like this sometimes equipment seems indestructible and other times shockingly fragile. There's always some degree of risk... But for my opinion it boils down to what happens if some thing goes wrong.... Personally one thing that worries about my M9 is what repair or replacement options might be available in the event of a disaster..
